item.title: Formally Verified Post-Quantum Cryptography
item.description: The US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) just released the first three standards for Post-Quantum KEMs (ML-KEM) and Signatures (ML-DSA, SLH-DSA).

item.title: Announcing the hax Playground
item.description: We’re proud to announce the hax playground! Inspired by the Rust Playground, the hax playground allows you to play with hax directly in your web browser!

item.title: Cryspen Welcomes Maxime

item.title: High Assurance IoT PQC
item.description: Together with our sister-company CryptoEng, we extend our libcrux cryptographic library with support for resource constrained IoT devices. Read their announcement here.

item.title: Cryspen @ FMCP 2024
item.description: The US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) publishes a number of important cryptographic standards (including upcoming ones for post-quantum cryptography), and runs the cryptographic algorithm and module validation programs that validate and issue certificates to cryptographic libraries.

item.title: Unlocking New Possibilities
item.description: We have been developing the hax toolchain over the last two years, in collaboration with research teams at Inria and the University of Aarhus.

item.title: Post-Quantum TLS in Bertie
item.description: The prospect of quantum computers breaking most public key encryption in use today has created the need for new schemes that can resist classical and potential quantum attackers alike.

item.title: Cryptographic protocol verification with hax
item.description: This blog post details an example of how to use our hax toolchain for verifying the security of cryptographic protocol implementations written in Rust.

item.title: Conference Talks
item.description: Cryspen attended a number of conference in April and March. Here is a list of all slides and videos. We will update links when more resources become available.

item.title: Post-Quantum OpenMLS
item.description: OpenMLS now offers security against harvest-now-decrypt-later (HNDL) quantum adversaries. In #1546 we merged support for the X-Wing KEM draft, which is an early draft for securely combining elliptic-curve-based Diffie-Hellman with ML-KEM.

item.title: Post-Quantum Group Messaging
item.description: With multiple post-quantum cryptographic algorithms (ML-KEM, ML-DSA) nearing standardization, enterprises, research groups, and standards bodies have started investigating what post-quantum secure protocols should look like and what properties they should satisfy.

item.title: Verifying Libcrux's ML-KEM
item.description: In a recent blog post, we described Cryspen’s new Rust implementation of ML-KEM in Rust, and talked about how our high-assurance development methodology helped us find a new timing bug in various other Kyber implementations.

item.title: Verified ML-KEM (Kyber) in Rust
item.description: ML-KEM, previously known as Kyber, is the first post-quantum secure key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM) to get standardised by NIST in FIPS 203.

item.title: An Analysis of Signal's PQXDH
item.description: Signal recently published a new, post-quantum secure, version of their X3DH protocol called PQXDH. As with any new cryptographic protocol, it is important to precisely analyse its security properties, especially for something as important as Signal.

item.title: Announcing Campus Cyber Circus Project
item.description: üéâ We’re excited to announce that Cryspen partnered with Inria on a transfer project to build a new integrated development and verification environment (IDVE).

item.title: Specifying Oblivious Pseudonymization
item.description: In this blog post we announce an executable specification in the hacspec specification language for the ScrambleDB pseudonymization system, developed by Cryspen as part of the BMBF ATLAS project.

item.title: Internet Defense Prize 2023
item.description: At the 32nd Usenix Security Symposium in Anaheim CA, a paper on the Messaging Layer Security Protocol, co-authored by our founders Jonathan Protzenko and Karthikeyan Bhargavan, was awarded both the Distinguished Paper Award and the prestigious Internet Defense Prize.

item.title: Prairie and Atlas
item.description: With the widespread adoption and deployment of machine learning across enterprises, ever-increasing amounts of data are being collected, stored, communicated, combined, and computed over by sophisticated algorithms.

item.description: ‚ÄúThree may keep a secret, if two of them are dead.‚Äù - Benjamin Franklin (1735) However skeptical we may be of our human ability to keep secrets, we still routinely participate in group conversations that we would like to keep away from prying eyes.

item.title: MLS - RFC 9420
item.description: ‚ú® We are thrilled to announce the release of the MLS specification as RFC 9420. RFC 9420 is a comprehensive description of the first standardised, efficient, asynchronous, key establishment protocol with forward secrecy and post-compromise security for groups in size ranging from two to thousands.

item.title: HACL Packages

item.description: Cryspen builds high assurance cryptography. But what does this actually mean? Before focusing on cryptography it is interesting to look at high assurance software in general.

item.description: HPKE, published as RFC 9180, describes a scheme for hybrid public key encryption. üìö Read our TL;DR on HPKE if you need more background on HPKE.

item.title: TL;DR - Hybrid Public Key Encryption
item.description: HPKE, defined in RFC 9180, is a CFRG standard that describes a scheme for hybrid public key encryption. It is co-authored by my Cryspen co-founder Karthikeyan Bhargavan and one of his PhD students Benjamin Lipp as part of his research at Inria.

item.title: Cryspen ERC PoC Grant
